# Hong Kong's Role as an International Financial Center

Hong Kong has maintained its position as a global offshore RMB business hub. Last year’s tax reforms helped create a favorable environment to attract multinational corporations to establish corporate treasury centers in the city. To develop Hong Kong into an infrastructure financing center and a fintech hub, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) established the Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office and the Fintech Facilitation Office during the year. The HKMA issued 13 licenses to operators of stored-value facilities during the year. Hong Kong’s sound fiscal performance and substantial net external assets continue to be affirmed by credit rating agencies, with Standard & Poor’s maintaining its AAA rating for Hong Kong.

# Overview

Affected by volatility in global financial markets and uncertainty surrounding the RMB exchange rate, global offshore RMB business slowed in 2016. Nevertheless, Hong Kong maintained its position as the world’s leading hub for offshore RMB business, processing approximately 70% of global RMB payment transactions. The launch of the Shenzhen-Hong Kong Stock Connect scheme in December marked another milestone in China’s capital account liberalization and an important step in enhancing Hong Kong’s status as an international financial center. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority also strengthened financial infrastructure by expanding its RMB liquidity provision and introducing measures to enhance RMB market transparency.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) established the Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office (IFFO) in July to promote infrastructure development and position Hong Kong as a hub for infrastructure financing. As of the end of January 2017, over 60 institutions had joined IFFO as partners. During the year, the HKMA also successfully drove the passage of legal amendments to eliminate tax asymmetries and provide tax incentives, encouraging multinational and Chinese companies to establish corporate treasury centers in Hong Kong, thereby creating more business opportunities for the financial and professional services sectors. The number of institutional investors operating in Hong Kong has also been gradually increasing, with the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority (ADIA), the world's third-largest sovereign wealth fund, announcing in October the establishment of an overseas office in Hong Kong, its only office outside of Abu Dhabi.

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) gave a positive evaluation of our efforts to strengthen Hong Kong’s position as an international financial center during its fourth Article IV consultation last year. Throughout the year, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) actively participated in international discussions, working to promote global and regional financial stability. The HKMA also maintained close communication with international credit rating agencies, which contributed to the confirmation of Hong Kong’s credit ratings by major agencies in 2016.

The safe and effective operation and sustained development of Hong Kong's financial infrastructure play a crucial role in reinforcing Hong Kong's competitiveness as an international financial center and a global offshore RMB business hub. In 2016, the four real-time gross settlement (RTGS) systems for interbank transactions and the Central Clearing System (CMU system) achieved 100% system availability, exceeding the target level of 99.95%.

In 2016, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority further strengthened Hong Kong’s retail payment financial infrastructure. Throughout the year, a total of 13 stored value facility licenses were issued under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance (the “Payment Ordinance”), which came into effect in November 2016. The coverage of electronic cheque services was also expanded to include cross-border payments between Hong Kong and Guangdong Province, including Shenzhen.

To promote the development of fintech in Hong Kong, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority established the Fintech Facilitation Office in March. Several key initiatives implemented throughout the year have achieved good progress.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has introduced a series of measures to strengthen the banking industry’s soft power, including (i) a program to enhance directors’ professional capabilities; (ii) establishing a professional qualification framework for banking professionals across the industry; and (iii) implementing a consumer education program.

# 2016 Year in Review

# Offshore Renminbi Services

Global financial market volatility and uncertainty surrounding the RMB exchange rate in 2016 led to a slowdown in offshore RMB business. By year-end, RMB customer deposits and certificates of deposit in Hong Kong totaled RMB 625.1 billion, a 38% decrease from the previous year (Figure 1). Offshore RMB bond issuance fell to RMB 52.8 billion during the year, and RMB trade settlement processed by Hong Kong banks also declined to RMB 4,542.1 billion.  However, RMB loans extended by Hong Kong banks remained stable at RMB 294.8 billion as of year-end (Figure 2).  Transaction volume in the RMB Real-Time Gross Settlement (RTGS) system remained high, averaging RMB 863.6 billion daily in 2016. This indicates that despite a reduction in RMB liquidity, Hong Kong continues to support substantial RMB financial intermediation. According to SWIFT data, Hong Kong processed approximately 70% of global RMB payment transactions in 2016, solidifying its position as a leading global hub for offshore RMB business.

Renminbi Customer Deposits and Certificates of Deposit

Figure 2: Renminbi Financing Activities

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) worked closely with relevant mainland authorities throughout the year to secure greater policy flexibility and promote RMB business in Hong Kong. Several new measures were launched, including further expanding access to the mainland’s interbank bond market and foreign exchange market, and the launch of Shenzhen-Hong Kong Stock Connect in December. In response to increasing demand for cross-border investment channels and liquidity management, the HKMA expanded its RMB liquidity arrangements. In October, the number of primary liquidity providers was increased from seven to nine, and the total quota of the program was raised from RMB 14 billion to RMB 18 billion. The HKMA also enhanced the transparency of its RMB liquidity facilities, helping participants more effectively manage their liquidity.

The national “13th Five-Year Plan,” released in March, reaffirmed Hong Kong’s position as a global RMB hub, demonstrating the central government’s support for its continued development as an offshore financial center.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continues to strengthen cooperation with other economies to develop offshore RMB business. The HKMA also actively participates in a range of events to promote Hong Kong as a global offshore RMB hub and a key platform for China’s overseas expansion strategy. This includes participation in local events organized by industry groups and private institutions, as well as overseas events in China, Germany, Kazakhstan, and the United Kingdom.

# Arrangement between the Mainland and Hong Kong Regarding Closer Economic and Trade Relations.

A new agreement under the Closer Economic Partnership Arrangement (CEPA) between the Mainland and Hong Kong, substantially liberalizing trade in services, was signed in 2015. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority continues to closely monitor the implementation of the current arrangement and collaborate with government authorities to explore further measures to expand market access and facilitate the Hong Kong financial sector’s operations in the Mainland market.

# Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office (IFFO)

# IFFO's Mission

IFFO’s mission is to foster infrastructure funding by bringing together key stakeholders. IFFO performs the following functions:
- Providing a platform for information exchange and experience sharing;
- Enhancing skills and knowledge in infrastructure investment and financing;
- Promoting market and product development; and
- Facilitating infrastructure investment activities.

Hong Kong Monetary Authority Chief Executive Eddie Yue (seventh from the left) toasted with other guests at the IFFO launch ceremony.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) established the Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office (IFFO) in July, with a mission to promote infrastructure investment and financing by facilitating collaboration among key stakeholders. As of the end of January 2017, over 60 institutions from China, Hong Kong, and overseas had joined IFFO as partners, including multilateral financial institutions and development banks, institutional investors, asset management companies, banks, insurance companies, infrastructure project developers and operators, professional service firms, and international trade associations (Table 1).

IFFO has made significant progress since its establishment. To enhance its capabilities, IFFO co-hosted an executive workshop in October with the International Finance Corporation, a member of the World Bank Group, and Hanwha Investment, focusing on investment and financing for private sector participation in infrastructure projects in emerging markets. The workshop received very positive feedback from participants, expanding their knowledge and fostering valuable connections. In November, IFFO held a high-level seminar featuring Mr. Jin Liqun, President of the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, who shared his expertise in infrastructure project planning, operation, and management. In July, IFFO signed Memoranda of Understanding (MOUs) with the International Finance Corporation and the Global Infrastructure Hub to establish a framework for cooperation. Subsequently, in December, MOUs were signed with the China Development Bank and the Export-Import Bank of China to facilitate infrastructure project financing through the IFFO platform. These initiatives strengthen Hong Kong’s role as a leading international infrastructure financing hub.

Mr. Chan Tak-lun, Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (left), and Mr. Philippe Le Houérou, Executive Vice President and Chief Executive Officer of the International Finance Corporation (right), signed a Memorandum of Understanding to foster collaboration through the IFFO platform, creating a more efficient and favorable market environment for infrastructure investment and financing in the region.

Hong Kong Monetary Authority Chief Executive Eddie Yue (left) and Global Infrastructure Hub Chief Executive Officer Chris Heathcote (right) signed a Memorandum of Understanding to establish a strategic cooperation framework to facilitate infrastructure project financing.

Mr. Chan Tak-lin, Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (left), and Mr. Hu Huai-bang, Chairman of the China Development Bank, signed a Memorandum of Understanding to enhance their collaboration.

# Corporate Finance Center

To further attract multinational companies to establish corporate treasury centers in Hong Kong, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is collaborating with the government to foster a favorable tax environment for these centers. Specifically, the Tax (Amendment) (No. 2) Ordinance 2016 (the “Amendment Ordinance”) was passed in June, allowing companies that meet certain requirements to deduct interest expenses incurred on internal financing within their group when calculating profits tax. Furthermore, qualifying corporate treasury centers will receive a 50% reduction in profits tax – lowering the rate to 8.25% – on profits generated from designated treasury activities. Table 2 briefly outlines the key provisions of the Amendment Ordinance.

In addition to its legislative work, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has been actively promoting the advantages of establishing corporate treasury centers in Hong Kong to multinational and Mainland Chinese enterprises. As of the end of the year, the HKMA had contacted nearly 400 companies, financial institutions, and industry organizations. In November, the HKMA also signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the Hong Kong China Enterprise Association to help Hong Kong-based China-based enterprises better understand and make greater use of the HKMA’s corporate treasury center platform.

# Promoting Asset Management Services

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority continues to promote Hong Kong as an asset management center. According to the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC), the number of licensed corporations engaged in asset management reached 1,300 by the end of 2016, an increase of nearly 15% year-on-year. According to the Asian Venture Capital Journal, the number of private equity firms in Hong Kong (including both SFC-licensed and non-SFC-licensed firms) also increased by 4.6% to 431 in 2016. Nearly 70 of the world’s top 100 asset management companies, as well as the majority of the top 20 mutual fund companies in China, have established operations or affiliated companies in Hong Kong. The number of institutional investors in Hong Kong is also steadily increasing; among them, the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, the world’s third-largest sovereign wealth fund, announced in October the establishment of an overseas office in Hong Kong—its only office outside of Abu Dhabi.

# Introducing the Open-Ended Investment Company Structure.

To attract funds to Hong Kong, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continues to work with the government and industry to foster a more favorable tax and regulatory environment. In June, the 2016 Securities and Futures (Amendment) Bill was passed, introducing an open-ended fund company structure. This diversifies Hong Kong’s fund registration platform, creates a more flexible operating environment for fund managers, and reinforces Hong Kong’s position as a leading international asset management center.

# Islamic finance

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continues to promote greater market awareness and understanding of Islamic finance, including collaborating with industry associations to host and participate in Islamic finance seminars and workshops. The HKMA also shares experiences with market participants regarding the issuance of Islamic bonds, encouraging them to leverage Hong Kong’s financial infrastructure. Following the successful issuance of the first two tranches of Islamic bonds, the HKMA is working closely with the government to launch a third tranche when market conditions are favorable.

# 儲備管理

2016年是充滿意外和黑天鵝事件的一年，環球金融市場出現大波動和震盪。2016年年初市場憂慮內地經濟硬着陸及全球增長放緩，促使環球股市大幅下挫。6月英國脫歐公投和11月美國大選結果亦出人意表。儘管投資環境困難，金管局在過去幾年已採取連串防禦措施，增強外匯基金的抗震能力，因此外匯基金在2016年仍錄得2% 的整體投資回報。

# 外匯基金

根據《外匯基金條例》，外匯基金的首要目的是直接或間接影響港元匯價，亦可運用於保持香港貨幣及金融體系穩定健全，藉此保持香港作為國際金融中心的地位。外匯基金由財政司司長掌有控制權，並投資於其經諮詢外匯基金諮詢委員會後認為合適的證券或其他資產。

# 外匯基金的管理

# 投資目標及組合結構

外匯基金諮詢委員會為外匯基金制定下列投資目標：
(a) 保障資本；
(b) 確保整體貨幣基礎在任何時候都由流通性極高的美元資產提供十足支持；
(c) 確保流動資金足以維持貨幣及金融穩定；以及
(d) 在符合上述(a)至(c)項的前提下盡量爭取投資回報，以保障基金的長期購買力。

以上目標全面顧及外匯基金的法定目的，並已於外匯基金的組合結構及目標資產分布中反映。

外匯基金大致上分成兩個主要組合：支持組合及投資組合。支持組合持有流通性極高的美元資產，按照貨幣發行局制度的規定為貨幣基礎提供十足支持。投資組合主要投資於經濟合作與發展組織成員國的債市及股市，以保障資產的價值及長期購買力。這兩個組合整體債券與股票的長線目標分布比率為71比29。以目標貨幣比重計，91%的資產分配予美元及港元，其餘9%分配予其他貨幣。

為能更妥善管理風險及提高中長期回報，金管局以審慎及循序漸進方式將外匯基金的部分資產分散投資至較多元化的資產類別，包括新興巿場及內地債券與股票、私募股權，以及海外投資物業。新興巿場及內地債券與股票由投資組合持有，私募股權及房地產投資則由長期增長組合持有。長期增長組合的市值上限為外匯基金累計盈餘的三分之一，但因應部分未來基金投放於長期資產，市值上限還有增加的空間。

策略性資產組合於2007年設立，以持有政府基於策略性目的而為外匯基金帳目購入的香港交易及結算所有限公司股份。由於這個組合性質獨特，因此外匯基金的投資表現評估並無將其包括在內。

# 於外匯基金的存款

外匯基金不時接受財政儲備、政府基金及法定組織的存款，利率一般與投資組合的表現掛鈎2，惟未來基金存款則除外。未來基金存款的利率與投資組合及長期增長組合的表現掛鈎，實際利率視乎組合比重而定。於2016年底，未來基金在投資組合與長期增長組合的比重為80：20。預期截至2018年底，未來基金存款中與長期增長組合掛鈎的部分會逐步增加至約50%。

# 投資程序

外匯基金的投資程序分別以策略性資產分布及戰略性資產分布作基礎。策略性資產分布，即投資基準反映的分布情況，顯示外匯基金為達到投資目標而可以作出的最佳長線資產分布。外匯基金以策略性分布作為指引，對資產進行戰略性分布，以爭取超越基準的回報。因此，實際分布往往會與基準分布（亦即策略性分布）有所偏離，而實際與基準分布之間的差距稱為「戰略性偏離」。財政司司長經諮詢外匯基金諮詢委員會後制定投資基準及戰略性偏離的限度，金管局獲授權決定戰略性資產分布。投資組合經理可在戰略性偏離的限度內選持倉盤，從短期市場變化中獲利。

# 投資管理

# 直接投資

金管局儲備管理部職員直接管理外匯基金約74%的投資，其中包括整個支持組合及部分投資組合。該部分投資組合投資於環球定息市場，並透過衍生工具執行外匯基金的宏觀風險管理策略。

# 外聘投資經理

除透過內部職員管理資產外，金管局亦僱用外聘投資經理負責管理外匯基金約26%的資產，其中包括所有上市股票組合及其他特別資產。僱用外聘投資經理的目的，是要運用市場上最佳的專業投資技術為外匯基金投資，並讓外匯基金受惠於多元化的投資方式，以及讓內部專業人員汲取市場知識與資訊。

僱用外聘投資經理的相關支出包括基金管理與託管費、交易費、預扣稅及其他稅項。這些支出主要受市場因素影響而每年不同。

金管局支持證券及期貨事務監察委員會於2016年3月7日發布的《負責任的擁有權原則》（《原則》）。《原則》屬自願性質，旨在協助投資者釐定如何以最佳方法履行其於香港上市公司的投資的擁有權責任。就外匯基金的管理而言，金管局鼓勵獲委任負責管理香港股票組合的外聘基金經理在管理有關投資時採納《原則》。

# 風險管理及監察

近年金融市場波動極大，凸顯風險管理的重要。金管局為內部及外聘投資經理所管理的投資組合均訂立嚴格管控措施及投資指引，並密切監察對指引及法規的遵守情況；另亦採用風險管控工具來評估在正常及極度不利市況下的市場風險。金管局亦進行詳細的投資表現因素分析，務求能最有效地運用內部及外聘投資經理的投資管理技術。

# Reserve Management

2016 was a year marked by unexpected events and black swan occurrences, triggering significant volatility in global financial markets. At the start of the year, concerns about a potential hard landing in the Chinese economy and a global growth slowdown led to a sharp decline in global stock markets. The outcomes of the UK’s referendum on EU membership in June and the US presidential election in November were also unforeseen. Despite this challenging investment environment, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) had implemented a series of defensive measures in previous years to strengthen the resilience of the Exchange Fund. Consequently, the Exchange Fund achieved an overall investment return of 2% in 2016.

# Exchange Fund

According to the Exchange Fund Ordinance, the primary objective of the Exchange Fund is to directly or indirectly influence the exchange rate of the Hong Kong dollar. It may also be used to maintain the stability of Hong Kong’s monetary and financial system, thereby preserving its position as an international financial center. The Exchange Fund is under the control of the Financial Secretary, who invests it in securities or other assets considered appropriate after consulting the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee.

# Management of the Foreign Exchange Fund

# Investment Objectives and Asset Allocation

The Exchange Fund Advisory Committee defines the following investment objectives for the Exchange Fund:
(a) Safeguarding capital;
(b) Ensuring the monetary base is fully supported by highly liquid U.S. dollar assets;
(c) Maintaining sufficient liquidity to support monetary and financial stability; and
(d) Seeking investment returns while adhering to the above objectives (a) to (c) to preserve the Fund’s long-term purchasing power.

These objectives are reflected in the Exchange Fund’s portfolio structure and target asset allocation, fully addressing its statutory purposes.

The Exchange Fund is broadly divided into two main portfolios: the Support Portfolio and the Investment Portfolio. The Support Portfolio holds highly liquid U.S. dollar assets, providing full backing for the monetary base in accordance with the Currency Board system. The Investment Portfolio primarily invests in the bond and stock markets of OECD member countries to preserve asset value and long-term purchasing power. The overall long-term target allocation ratio of bonds to stocks across both portfolios is 71% to 29%.  91% of assets are allocated to U.S. dollars and Hong Kong dollars, with the remaining 9% allocated to other currencies.

To more effectively manage risks and enhance long-term returns, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority is prudently diversifying a portion of the Exchange Fund’s assets into a broader range of asset classes, including emerging markets and Mainland China bonds and equities, private equity, and overseas real estate investments. Emerging market and Mainland bonds and equities are held in the investment portfolio, while private equity and real estate investments are held in the long-term growth portfolio. The market value cap for the long-term growth portfolio is set at one-third of the Exchange Fund’s accumulated surplus, but there is potential to increase this cap as future fund allocations are directed towards long-term assets.

The Strategic Asset Portfolio was established in 2007 to hold shares in Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited, purchased by the Exchange Fund for strategic purposes. Given the portfolio’s unique characteristics, its performance is not incorporated into the Exchange Fund’s investment performance evaluation.

# Deposits in the Exchange Fund.

The Exchange Fund periodically accepts deposits from fiscal reserves, government funds, and statutory organizations, with interest rates generally tied to the performance of its investment portfolio, except for deposits from the Future Fund. Interest on Future Fund deposits is linked to the performance of both the investment portfolio and the long-term growth portfolio, with the actual rate determined by the allocation between the two. At the end of 2016, the Future Fund’s allocation was 80% to the investment portfolio and 20% to the long-term growth portfolio. It is anticipated that the proportion of Future Fund deposits linked to the long-term growth portfolio will gradually increase to around 50% by the end of 2018.

# Investment Process

The Exchange Fund’s investment process is based on a framework of strategic and tactical asset allocation. Strategic asset allocation defines the optimal long-term asset mix for achieving the Fund’s investment objectives, serving as a reference point for portfolio construction. The Exchange Fund then employs tactical asset allocation, guided by this strategic framework, to seek returns exceeding the benchmark. Consequently, the actual asset allocation will often vary from the strategic allocation, and this difference is defined as a “strategic variance.” The Financial Secretary, after consulting the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, establishes the investment benchmark and the limits for strategic variance, while the Hong Kong Monetary Authority is authorized to determine the tactical asset allocation. Portfolio managers can then manage holdings within these variance limits to capitalize on short-term market opportunities.

# Investment Management

# Direct Investment

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s Reserve Management Department directly manages approximately 74% of the Exchange Fund’s investments, including the entire supporting portfolio and a portion of the investment portfolio. This portion of the investment portfolio is invested in global fixed-income markets and implements the Exchange Fund’s macro risk management strategies through derivatives.

# External Investment Manager

In addition to managing assets through its internal staff, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) employs external investment managers to manage approximately 26% of the Exchange Fund’s assets, including all listed equity portfolios and other special assets. The purpose of engaging these external managers is to leverage the best professional investment expertise available in the market for the Fund’s investments, benefit from diversified investment strategies, and enable internal professionals to gain market insights and knowledge.

Expenses related to engaging external investment managers include fund management and custody fees, transaction costs, withholding taxes, and other taxes. Market factors primarily drive these expenses, causing them to vary annually.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority supports the Securities and Futures Commission’s “Principles of Responsible Ownership” (“the Principles”) issued on March 7, 2016. The Principles are voluntary and aim to help investors determine how best to fulfill their ownership responsibilities in companies listed in Hong Kong. Concerning the management of the Exchange Fund, the HKMA encourages externally appointed fund managers responsible for managing the Hong Kong equity portfolio to adopt the Principles when managing these investments.

# Risk Management and Monitoring

In recent years, financial market volatility has underscored the importance of risk management. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has established strict control measures and investment guidelines for investment portfolios managed by both internal and external investment managers, and closely monitors compliance with these guidelines and regulations. It also employs risk management tools to assess market risks under both normal and severely adverse market conditions. Furthermore, the HKMA conducts detailed analyses of investment performance factors to ensure the most effective use of the investment management expertise of both internal and external managers.

# Performance of the Foreign Exchange Fund

# Financial Markets in 2016

Global financial markets experienced significant volatility in 2016. In January, concerns about a potential economic slowdown in China and globally triggered sharp declines in Hong Kong and other major stock markets, which did not fully recover until mid-February. The outcomes of the UK’s Brexit referendum in June and the US presidential election in November both defied expectations, yet stock markets quickly rebounded from initial dips. Overall, global stock markets performed well for the year.

In the bond market, falling commodity prices in the first quarter intensified concerns about slowing global growth and low inflation. These concerns, alongside uncertainty stemming from the UK’s Brexit referendum in the second quarter and expectations of continued accommodative monetary policy from central banks, boosted demand for safe assets and supported strong performance in government bond markets during the first half of 2016. The yield on the 10-year U.S. Treasury note declined to a record low of 1.36% in July. However, yields rose sharply in the second half of the year as expectations of U.S. interest rate increases grew, particularly following the U.S. presidential election. Yields on other major government bonds also increased, though to a lesser degree.

In the currency market, the US dollar continued to strengthen in 2016, with the dollar index reaching a 14-year high. This strength was supported by widening interest rate differentials between the dollar and other major currencies. While the Japanese yen rose approximately 3% versus the dollar in 2016, the euro fell around 3%. Following the uncertainty caused by the Brexit referendum, the British pound also declined by 16% against the dollar during the year, representing its largest drop since 2008.

# Performance of the Foreign Exchange Fund

Despite significant volatility in the financial markets, the Exchange Fund generated HK$68.1 billion in investment income in 2016, including HK$28.6 billion from overseas equities, HK$5.3 billion from Hong Kong equities, HK$33.1 billion from bonds, and HK$16.9 billion from other investments held by its investment holding subsidiaries. At the end of 2016, the Exchange Fund’s total assets reached HK$361.87 billion. The market value of its long-term growth portfolio investments totaled HK$181.8 billion, including HK$116.8 billion in private equity and HK$65 billion in real estate. A total of HK$133.8 billion had been committed but not yet drawn down for investment.

Despite a challenging investment climate, the Exchange Fund achieved a 2% investment return in 2016 (excluding its strategic asset portfolio). The long-term growth portfolio has generated an annualized internal rate of return of approximately 12% since its inception in 2009.

Due to the continued deterioration of the external investment environment, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has implemented a series of defensive measures in recent years, including shortening the maturity of the bond portfolio, increasing cash holdings, and significantly reducing assets denominated in currencies other than US dollars and Hong Kong dollars. We have also accelerated the pace of diversifying our investments, particularly in our long-term growth portfolio. These measures have significantly enhanced the resilience of the Exchange Fund.

# 公共傳訊

金管局與傳媒保持緊密聯繫，以提高金管局的透明度，並增進公眾對其政策和工作的了解。金管局在2016年共進行了81次公開媒體活動，包括14次新聞發布會、13次即場訪問和54次其他公開活動，並安排了30次媒體訪談。年內發布326份雙語新聞稿，每日亦處理大量傳媒查詢。

# 人手編制

金管局於2016年初的人手編制為875人，2016年下半年增設12個職位，以履行金管局在新保險業監管制度下的監管職能。因此，金管局在2016年底的人手編制為887人。

為確保有足夠資源實行新法例和政策、繼續推進須持續的試行項目，以及處理現有日益繁重和複雜的工作，金管局的整體編制於2017年增加40人至927人（增幅4.5%）。新增職位負責執行以下職能：
- 促進銀行及金融體系穩定，包括：

    - 加強打擊清洗黑錢及恐怖分子資金籌集活動的監管及執法工作，並為2018年打擊清洗黑錢財務特別行動組織相互評估計劃作好準備；
    - 作好實施《金融機構（處置機制）條例》的規劃及籌備工作，以根據國際標準處理金融業「大到不能倒」的問題；及
    - 加強監理能力以配合有關資本及市場風險的新國際標準，並增撥資源處理消費者保障事宜及銀行投訴。
- 因應進一步推動外匯基金投資產品多元化所牽涉的更多投資工作，加強投資、風險管理及其他相關支援，同時強化策略性資產分配及投資程序，以應對挑戰日增的投資環境。
- 制定及實施人才發展計劃，並加強相關資源，確保金管局具備所需的人力資源應對市場發展及未來的挑戰。
- 加強貨幣政策方面的研究及貨幣統計資料的處理，以及提供資源處理就儲值支付工具及零售支付系統的牌照╱指定及相關監管事宜而作出的查詢及投訴。

# 薪酬福利政策及薪酬檢討機制

財政司司長透過外匯基金諮詢委員會聽取其轄下管治委員會提供的意見，並參考市場薪酬水平及做法，決定金管局員工的薪酬及服務條件。薪酬組合包括現金薪酬及公積金，另設一些基本福利。現金薪酬包括每月固定薪酬（即基本薪酬）及根據員工工作表現每年一次過發放的浮動薪酬。

財政司司長每年檢討金管局員工薪酬時，會透過外匯基金諮詢委員會聽取其轄下管治委員會的建議，並考慮管治委員會對金管局過去一年的表現評估、獨立人力資源顧問公司進行的金融業薪酬調查結果，以及其他相關因素。個別工作表現優秀的員工的薪酬亦可能獲得特別調整，以保持其薪酬競爭力。

金管局按個別員工的工作表現，分配獲批准用作調整年度固定薪酬或發放浮動薪酬的款項；而用於專業投資人員的浮動薪酬制度，則旨在加強其投資表現與薪酬的連繫。助理總裁或以上職級員工的固定薪酬調整或浮動薪酬的發放，是由財政司司長經參考管治委員會的意見後批准，有關員工在會議討論到其薪酬的議案時會避席。主管及以下職級員工的固定薪酬調整或浮動薪酬的發放，則由金管局總裁根據財政司司長授權，並按照獲批准用作支付薪酬的整筆款項來決定。

# Institutional Functions

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) maintains effective communication with the public and the market through the media, public education activities, and various other channels, enhancing public understanding of its policies and operations. Throughout the year, the HKMA continued to strengthen its institutional governance, including promoting staff professional development, exercising stringent financial control, and enhancing information technology security, to address the challenges posed by the implementation of new measures and an increasing workload.

# Institutional Development through Public Engagement

# Public Notice

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) maintains close communication with the media to enhance transparency and foster public understanding of its policies and operations. In 2016, the Authority conducted 81 public media engagements, including 14 press conferences, 13 stand-up interviews, and 54 other public appearances, alongside arranging 30 media interviews. It issued 326 bilingual press releases throughout the year and handled a substantial number of media inquiries daily.

This year, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) launched two important offices: the Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office (IFFO) and the FinTech Facilitation Office (FFO). To explain their functions and work plans, the HKMA undertook a series of public outreach initiatives. Furthermore, the HKMA hosted press briefings and seminars to enhance public understanding of its operations and measures relating to financial inclusion, reserve management, the FinTech regulatory sandbox, cybersecurity, and SME financing.

Norman Chan, Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, met with reporters during the Hong Kong Bankers' Association's annual trip to Beijing in December 2016.

# Public Inquiries

The Public Inquiry Service is an effective channel for citizens to obtain information on the functions and work of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA). This service handled 10,170 inquiries in 2016, a 12% increase compared to 2015. Approximately half of the inquiries concerned banking policies and regulations, monetary and economic matters, and banking consumer issues, particularly relating to banking products and services, the coin collection program, banking-related guidelines and announcements, stored-value payment facilities and retail payment systems, combating money laundering and terrorist financing, and prudential regulatory measures for property mortgage loans.

Figure 1 shows the number of public inquiries received each year since 2013, and Figure 2 details the breakdown of inquiries by category in 2016.

# Publications

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) publishes, in addition to its Annual Report, two issues of the Semi-Annual Report on Monetary and Financial Stability and four issues of the Quarterly Report. It also regularly updates the Monthly Financial Data Bulletin, providing the latest data and thematic analysis on Hong Kong’s monetary affairs, banking sector, and economy. Furthermore, the HKMA published 32 articles in its “Insights” series in 2016, a significant increase from the 14 published in 2015, elaborating on a variety of topics related to the HKMA’s work.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s 2015 Annual Report won a Silver Award in the “Non-profit and Charitable Organizations” category at the Hong Kong Management Association’s 2016 Annual Report Awards.

# Public Education Program

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority Information Centre is located on the 55th floor of International Finance Centre Phase 2. It provides information about the HKMA’s work and promotes public understanding of monetary and banking matters. The Centre features an exhibition hall and a library, both open to the public six days a week. The exhibition hall details the HKMA’s role and the development of Hong Kong’s banking industry, while the library offers reading materials and exhibits for research on Hong Kong’s currency, banking, and financial affairs.

The Information Centre’s policy exhibition area, which explains the work of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and introduces related financial knowledge, underwent renovation in the fourth quarter of 2016. The renovated exhibition features enriched content and a variety of interactive elements, including games designed to make learning about finance engaging and accessible. Visitors can also explore comprehensive information about the Hong Kong Monetary Authority through visually appealing touch-screen displays. The renovation aimed to provide a fresh and immersive experience. In addition, the Information Centre now showcases a mosaic artwork of Victoria Harbour, created from over 130,000 Hong Kong coins. The revamped policy exhibition area reopened to the public on February 24, 2017.

# Hong Kong Monetary Authority Website

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s official website (www.hkma.gov.hk) provides over 50,000 pages of information in English and both Traditional and Simplified Chinese, making it easy for the public to access the latest updates from the HKMA. The website also hosts the “Register of Securities Dealers of Authorized Institutions” and the “Register of Authorized Institutions and Local Representatives,” maintained under Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance, as well as the “Register of Licensed Stored Value Facility Operators” maintained under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance. The website features dedicated pages and highlighted links to inform the public about new HKMA measures, such as the regulatory framework for stored value facilities, IFFO and FFO, and important timely information, including warnings about telephone fraud and the locations of coin collection vehicles.

A mosaic of the Victoria Harbour skyline created from Hong Kong coins.

The Information Center provides guided tours for visitors. This year, the center welcomed over 56,200 visitors and conducted more than 580 guided tours for schools and other groups (Figure 3). Since opening in December 2003, the center has hosted a total of over 586,600 visitors.

The library, adjacent to the Exhibition Hall, holds over 23,000 books, journals, and other publications for in-depth research on Hong Kong currency, banking, finance, and central banking. It also maintains an electronic register of approved institutions and their local representative offices, as well as employees engaged in securities business, under Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance.

To maintain close ties with the community and enhance public understanding of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s work, the HKMA continues to host public education talks. In 2016, the Authority held three talks, attracting over 1,750 secondary school students and teachers. Topics included the linked exchange rate system, banking system stability, Hong Kong banknotes, helpful tips for using banking products and services, and the Deposit Protection Scheme. Since 1998, these educational talks have been attended by over 56,400 members of the public.

# Human Resources

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) employs, trains, and retains a professional and highly capable workforce to achieve its policy objectives and adapt flexibly to changing priorities. As part of the government structure, the HKMA hires staff under non-civil service terms to attract individuals with appropriate experience and specialized knowledge. As a public institution, the HKMA is committed to maintaining a lean and flexible organizational structure and, wherever possible, implements new initiatives and manages increasing workloads by reallocating existing staff.

# Staff Complement

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) had a headcount of 875 at the beginning of 2016. In the second half of the year, 12 positions were added to meet its regulatory responsibilities under the new insurance regulatory regime. Consequently, the HKMA’s headcount rose to 887 by the end of 2016.

To ensure sufficient resources for implementing new legislation and policies, continuing ongoing pilot programs, and managing the increasing workload, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) increased its overall staffing by 40 to 927 employees (a 4.5% increase) in 2017. The newly created positions support the following functions:
- Promoting the stability of the banking and financial system, including:
    - Enhancing supervisory capacity to manage growing technological risks and new fintech initiatives within banks, as well as addressing their regional and business expansion;
    - Strengthening regulatory and enforcement efforts to combat money laundering and terrorist financing, and preparing for the 2018 Mutual Evaluation Program under the Financial Action Task Force (FATF);
    - Planning and preparing for the implementation of the Financial Institutions (Resolution Mechanism) Ordinance to address the “too big to fail” issue in the financial sector in accordance with international standards; and
    - Enhancing supervisory capacity to align with new international standards on capital and market risk, and allocating additional resources to handle consumer protection matters and bank complaints.
- Strengthening investment, risk management, and related support functions in response to increased investment activity related to the diversification of the HKMA’s Exchange Fund investment products, while reinforcing strategic asset allocation and investment processes to address the evolving investment environment.
- Developing and implementing talent development programs and enhancing related resources to ensure the HKMA has the necessary human resources to address market developments and future challenges.
- Strengthening research on monetary policy and the processing of monetary statistics, as well as providing resources to handle inquiries and complaints relating to the licensing and regulation of stored-value facilities and retail payment systems.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) allocates temporary resources to handle other tasks and seconds staff to international or local institutions, such as the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the Financial Development Bureau, to assist with work or policies involving Hong Kong or the HKMA. Additionally, the HKMA second staff to the Hong Kong Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Hong Kong Association of Banks to provide full-time or supporting operational assistance.

# Compensation and Benefits Policy and Compensation Review and Adjustment Process

The Financial Secretary determines the compensation and terms of service for Hong Kong Monetary Authority staff, based on advice from advisory committees under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee and with reference to market salary levels and practices. The compensation package includes cash salary and a provident fund, as well as basic benefits. Cash salary comprises a fixed monthly component (basic salary) and an annual variable payment based on employee performance.

The Financial Secretary annually reviews the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s (HKMA) staff compensation, consulting the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, which considers recommendations from the HKMA’s Governance Committee. This review takes into account the Governance Committee’s assessment of the HKMA’s performance over the past year, the results of financial industry compensation surveys conducted by independent human resources consulting firms, and other relevant factors. Individual employees with outstanding performance may also receive special compensation adjustments to ensure their competitiveness.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority allocates approved funds for adjusting annual fixed salaries or disbursing variable pay based on individual employee performance. The variable pay system for professional investment personnel is designed to strengthen the link between their investment performance and compensation. Adjustments to fixed salaries or the disbursement of variable pay for employees at the level of Assistant General Manager or above require approval from the Financial Secretary, after considering the views of the Governance Committee, and these employees will not participate in discussions regarding their own compensation. For employees at the level of Manager or below, adjustments to fixed salaries or the disbursement of variable pay are determined by the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, under the authorization of the Financial Secretary, and in accordance with the total approved amount allocated for salary payments.

- 審視有關存款及所賺取的利息在財務報表中的列報方式及披露資料。

# 按公平值列帳的投資物業的估值

請參閱財務報表附註2.12、17及18。

集團的投資物業按公平值列帳，於2016年12月31日共值227.23億港元。集團亦於3間聯營公司及14間合營公司擁有權益，該等公司主要業務為持有海外投資物業，有關權益共值320.83億港元。不論是由集團直接持有或由聯營公司或合營公司持有，該等投資物業的公平值均主要根據獨立專業估值師的估值釐定。該等估值涉及重大判斷及估計，包括所用的估值方法及假設。

就按公平值列帳的投資物業的估值，審計程序包括：
- 獲取及審視由集團直接持有或由聯營公司或合營公司持有的投資物業的估值報告，並核實公平值是根據有關估值報告所列的估值釐定；

# 其他資料

# 金融管理專員及外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會就財務報表而須承擔的責任

金融管理專員須負責按照香港會計師公會頒布的《香港財務報告準則》及行政長官在《外匯基金條例》第7條下所發出的指示擬備真實而公平的財務報表，及落實其認為必要的內部控制，使財務報表不存有因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述。

在擬備財務報表時，金融管理專員須負責評估集團持續經營的能力， 以及在適用情況下披露與持續經營有關的事項，並以持續經營作為會計基礎。

外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會負責監督集團的財務報告過程。

# 審計師就財務報表審計而須承擔的責任

我的目標是就整體財務報表是否不存有任何因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述取得合理保證，並發出包括我意見的審計師報告。合理保證是高水平的保證，但不能確保按審計署審計準則進行的審計定能發現所存有的任何重大錯誤陳述。錯誤陳述可以由欺詐或錯誤引起，如果合理預期它們個別或滙總起來可能影響財務報表使用者所作出的經濟決定，則會被視作重大錯誤陳述。

在根據審計署審計準則進行審計的過程中，我會運用專業判斷並秉持專業懷疑態度。我亦會：
- 識別和評估因欺詐或錯誤而導致財務報表存有重大錯誤陳述的風險；設計及執行審計程序以應對這些風險；以及取得充足和適當的審計憑證，作為我意見的基礎。由於欺詐可能涉及串謀、偽造、蓄意遺漏、虛假陳述，或凌駕內部控制的情況，因此未能發現因欺詐而導致重大錯誤陳述的風險，較未能發現因錯誤而導致者為高；
- 了解與審計相關的內部控制，以設計適當的審計程序。然而，此舉並非旨在對集團內部控制的有效性發表意見；
- 評價金融管理專員所採用的會計政策是否恰當，以及其作出的會計估計和相關資料披露是否合理；
- 判定金融管理專員以持續經營作為會計基礎的做法是否恰當，並根據所得的審計憑證，判定是否存在與事件或情況有關，而且可能對集團持續經營的能力構成重大疑慮的重大不確定性。如果我認為存在重大不確定性，則有必要在審計師報告中請使用者留意財務報表中的相關資料披露。假若所披露的相關資料不足，我便須發出非無保留意見的審計師報告。我的結論是基於截至審計師報告日止所取得的審計憑證。然而，未來事件或情況可能導致集團不能繼續持續經營；
- 評價財務報表的整體列報方式、結構和內容，包括披露資料，以及財務報表是否公允反映交易和事項；及
- 就集團中實體或業務活動的財務資料獲取充足和適當的審計憑證，以對財務報表發表意見。我負責指導、監督和執行集團審計。我對我的審計意見承擔全部責任。

我會與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通計劃的審計範圍和時間以及重大審計發現等事項，包括我在審計期間識別出內部控制的任何重大缺陷。

How should I handle relevant matters during an audit?

# Fair Value Measurement of Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities

Please refer to Notes 2.5, 2.6, and 36.1 of the financial statements.

As of December 31, 2016, the Group’s financial assets measured at fair value totaled HK$31,989.75 billion, and financial liabilities totaled HK$9,639.77 billion.

The fair value of 95% of these financial assets and all of these financial liabilities is determined by quoted prices for identical assets or liabilities in active markets (Level 1 inputs), or is estimated using valuation techniques with inputs based on observable market data (Level 2 inputs).

The fair value of the remaining 5% of these financial assets is estimated using valuation techniques, with parameters not based on observable market data (Level 3 parameters). These financial assets total HKD 175.886 billion, primarily consisting of unlisted investment funds.

Given the significant amounts involved and the need for estimates, the valuation of financial assets and financial liabilities measured at fair value is a key audit matter.

Audit procedures for the valuation of financial assets and financial liabilities measured at fair value include:
- Understanding the valuation processes for different categories of financial assets and liabilities, including associated controls;
- Evaluating and testing these controls, including application controls within computer systems;
- Obtaining confirmation regarding the valuation, existence, rights and obligations, and completeness of financial assets and liabilities;
- Verifying prices against independent sources when market quotations are used;
- If the valuation method’s parameters are based on observable market data, assessing the appropriateness of the method and the reasonableness of underlying assumptions, and verifying the parameters against independent sources; and
- If the valuation method’s parameters are not based on observable market data, assessing the appropriateness of the method and the reasonableness of the assumptions and parameters used.

# Future Fund Deposits

Notes to the financial statements 2.6, 2.16.1, 4(b), 23, and 28.

In prior years, the vast majority of deposits in the fiscal reserve were repayable as needed and earned interest at a fixed rate determined annually based on the past returns of the reference portfolio.

The Government established the Future Fund within its fiscal reserves on January 1, 2016. The Fund was initially capitalized with HK$219.73 billion from the Land Fund surplus, and receives regular contributions from the government’s general revenue account as directed by the Financial Secretary. Interest earned on the Future Fund’s deposits is calculated based on a composite rate, determined annually on a weighted average basis, referencing both a fixed rate linked to the investment portfolio’s performance and the annual return of a long-term growth portfolio (investing in private equity and real estate). Unless otherwise directed by the Financial Secretary, the Future Fund’s deposits and accrued interest will be repaid by December 31, 2025.

As of December 31, 2016, the Future Fund maintained deposits totaling HK$224.53 billion. Accumulated interest earned on these deposits amounted to HK$10.071 billion. Due to the substantial amounts involved and significant changes to the deposit terms, careful attention must be given to how these deposits and the associated interest are measured, presented, and disclosed.

The audit procedures for future fund deposits include:
- Assessing the appropriateness of the accounting policies used to value the deposits and related interest earned;
- Examining the methodology for calculating the annual rate of return linked to the long-term growth portfolio’s performance;
- Confirming the calculation of the fixed interest rate based on the historical performance of the benchmark portfolio, the annual rate of return linked to the long-term growth portfolio’s performance, and the composite rate derived from these two rates;
- Confirming the amount of accrued interest calculated using the composite rate; and
- Reviewing the presentation and disclosure of the deposits and related interest earned in the financial statements.

# Valuation of Investment Property Accounted for at Fair Value

Please refer to Notes 2.12, 17, and 18 of the financial statements.

The Group’s investment properties are accounted for at fair value, totaling HK$22.7 billion as of December 31, 2016. The Group also holds interests in three associate companies and fourteen joint ventures, whose primary business is the holding of overseas investment properties, with these interests valued at HK$32.1 billion. The fair value of these investment properties, whether held directly by the Group or through associate companies or joint ventures, is primarily determined based on valuations by independent professional valuers. These valuations involve significant judgment and estimates, including the valuation methods and assumptions used.

The audit procedures for the valuation of investment properties accounted for at fair value include:
- Obtaining and reviewing valuation reports for investment properties held directly by the Group or by associates and joint ventures, and verifying that the fair value is determined based on the valuations stated in the relevant reports;
- Assessing the independence and qualifications of the valuers; and
- Evaluating the appropriateness of the valuation methods and the reasonableness of the related assumptions and parameters.

# The responsibilities of the Audit Committee, under the Commissioner of Financial Management and within the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, regarding financial statements.

The Financial Management Officer is responsible for preparing true and fair financial statements in accordance with the Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards issued by the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants and the instructions issued by the Chief Executive under section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance, and for implementing internal controls they consider necessary to ensure that the financial statements do not contain material misstatements resulting from fraud or error.

# Auditors’ Responsibilities for the Audit of Financial Statements

My objective is to obtain reasonable assurance regarding whether the financial statements are free from material misstatement due to fraud or error, and to issue an auditor’s report that includes my opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but it does not guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with auditing standards will detect any material misstatements that may exist. Misstatements can arise from fraud or error, and are considered material if they, individually or in aggregate, could reasonably be expected to influence the economic decisions of users of the financial statements.

During the audit conducted in accordance with auditing standards, I will apply professional judgment and maintain professional skepticism. I will also:
- Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement in the financial statements arising from fraud or error; design and perform audit procedures to address those risks; and obtain sufficient appropriate audit evidence to support my opinion. - Understand internal controls relevant to the audit to design appropriate audit procedures. However, this does not involve expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Group’s internal controls;
- Evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies adopted by management and the reasonableness of accounting estimates and related disclosures;
- Determine whether management’s use of the going concern basis of accounting is appropriate, and based on the audit evidence obtained, whether there are material uncertainties related to events or conditions that may cast significant doubt on the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern. - Evaluate the overall presentation, structure, and content of the financial statements, including disclosures, and whether the financial statements fairly present the transactions and events; and
- Obtain sufficient appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of entities or business activities within the Group to form an opinion on the financial statements. I am responsible for directing, supervising, and performing the Group audit and am fully responsible for my audit opinion.

I will communicate with the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee regarding the audit scope and timeline, and discuss any significant findings, including material weaknesses in internal controls identified during the audit.
